awd_titl_txt: VLBA Operations and Reintegration into NRAO
awd_abstract_narration:
Associated Universities, Inc. (AUI) through the National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) will manage the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) from October 1, 2018 to September 30, 2026. The research community will be provided cutting-edge capabilities of micro-arcsecond astrometry, the highest resolution imaging telescope at any wavelength.  The VLBA will operate with state-of-the art instrumentation, advanced data processing, and broad user support, enabling the entire astronomy community to address key problems in astronomy and astrophysics. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The opportunities for astronomy and astrophysics research have never been richer. The VLBA will complement the next generation of large ground based optical telescopes and space-based facilities covering the entire electromagnetic spectrum. Together they comprise a comprehensive suite of powerful tools to probe and decipher the full range of outstanding problems, from the origin of planets, stars, quasars and galaxies, to the structure of the Universe and the nature of dark matter and dark energy. Observations with VLBA will shed new light on  exoplanets, and planetary and stellar formation and evolution.  Microarcsecond astrometry is making possible a new class of precision measurements of the parallax of pre-main sequence stars, recoil motions of stars in response to exoplanets, the structure of the Galaxy and the dynamics of the Local Group of galaxies.  Multi-epoch high resolution images will lead to a better understanding of relativistic jets from micro-quasars and supermassive black holes found in Active Galactic Nuclei, along with the nature of gamma-ray bursts seen by the GLAST satellite.  Observations will provide the angular-diameter distance determination of galaxies in the Hubble flow, leading to a more accurate determination of the Hubble Constant, higher precision determination of cosmological constants, and better constraints on the equation of state of dark energy. 

BROADER IMPACT: NRAO facilities are used by more than one thousand scientists each year and are available to all scientists based on the intellectual merits of the proposed studies, independent of institutional or national affiliation. NRAO will provide end-to-end user support at its science centers, enabling easy access to its telescope and their data by the entire astronomical community. Calibrated images will be made available in archives accessible to both the broad research community and the public. Astronomy is an important element in meeting national goals related to diversity, science and technology education, and increased U.S. competitiveness. NRAO is attracting an increasingly diverse staff. Through the undergraduate Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and co-op programs, resident graduate fellowships and external student grants, Green Bank and Socorro summer schools, and competitive postdoctoral Jansky Fellowships, it continues to help train the next generation of scientists. The Green Bank Science Center, the VLA Visitors Center, US-Chile teacher/student exchange programs, and teacher and K-12 education programs, further serve to create a science-literate public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to continue maintenance and operations of the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA). The VLBA consists of ten 25-m diameter radio antennas spread across the US, including Hawaii and the island of St. Croix, which together act as a single telescope capable of imaging astronomical objects at extremely high angular resolution. The VLBA is especially useful at studying black holes at the centers of galaxies, pulsars, certain classes of stars, and the gas clouds surrounding forming stars. Two years prior to the start of this award the VLBA split off from the NRAO and was operated by the Long Baseline Observatory (LBO). With this award that action was undone, returning the VLBA to the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. Reintegration included activities such as retiring the LBO branding and reintegrating organization charts. 

Operations of the VLBA includes two calls for proposals each year allowing scientists from anywhere in the world to propose novel uses of the VLBA. Successful proposers then submit observing files for the VLBA operations staff to execute. Data is preprocessed (correlated) and archived, at which point the scientist can access the data. The four years of operation included the pandemic period requiring innovative solutions to operations. The VLBA never stopped observing due to the pandemic.

In addition to supporting VLBA-only observing, the VLBA participates with other radio telescopes around the world such as the Global Millimeter VLBI Array and the High Sensitivity Array. Observing in these extended arrays requires significantly more coordination and can yield results unachievable using any other instrument.In addition to continual maintenance work conducted by onsite technicians, operations also include major maintenance to the array. Each year two or three sites receive a two-week duration preventative maintenance visit which includes a wide variety of tasks such as painting, lubrication, cleaning, repairs to mechanical structures, and grounds maintenance. Additionally, reactive maintenance visits are performed as needed after failures. In the four-year period there were issues with the HVAC systems, wheels, bearings, and motors requiring special visits. Additionally, a major wildfire surrounded the Kitt Peak VLBA antenna in June, 2022. While the VLBA building and antenna were not directly affected, restoration of the road and utilities took many months.

Improvements and infrastructure reinvestments were made under this award. The operator's console was renovated. A new hydrogen maser was procured (essential for accurate time-keeping), the computer cluster that hosts the VLBA correlator was replaced with modern servers and new diagnostic tools (e.g., spectrum analyzers) were purchased for each VLBA site. Several engineering efforts began including a new flexible frequency synthesizer, improved equipment rack in the antennas, new data acquisition and digital signal processing equipment, and replacements for the motor control electronics. The VLBA worked closely with JPL in the development of a new very wide-band receiver (8-36 GHz) that may ultimately be installed on each VLBA antenna.

Some new user-visible capabilities were made available as well. The data rate was doubled, allowing a 41% increase in sensitivity through the introduction of a new data recorder. A new, long desired observing mode was introduced allowing the VLBA to simultaneously observe with three antennas from the Very Large Array, enhancing the VLBA's ability to image large astrophysical structures. Another long-desired capability was introduced: the ability to correlate data from all VLBA antennas in real-time. The wide-area network connections are still too limited to allow this at full data rate, but this capability has demonstrated its utility in the form of diagnostics which are performed multiple times each week.
